head.title: Wrestler Fails Drug Test and May Lose Gold

hedline.hl1: Wrestler Fails Drug Test and May Lose Gold

abstract.p: International Olympic Committee's medical commission recommends that gold medal be taken from German freestyle wrestler Alexander Leipold because he tested positive for steroid nandrolone at Summer Games in Sydney (M)

block.p: The International Olympic Committee's medical commission recommended yesterday that the gold medal be taken from a German freestyle wrestler because he tested positive for the steroid nandrolone at the Summer Games in Sydney, Australia.

The International Olympic Committee's medical commission recommended yesterday that the gold medal be taken from a German freestyle wrestler because he tested positive for the steroid nandrolone at the Summer Games in Sydney, Australia.
If the I.O.C.'s executive board upholds the commission's ruling on Alexander Leipold, the gold medal in the 167.5-pound class will be awarded to an American, Brandon Slay.
Leipold would become the third athlete at the Sydney Games to lose a gold medal because of a drug offense.
''I have always dreamed of and worked toward the goal of winning an Olympic gold medal,'' Slay said in a statement. ''But this certainly wasn't the way I dreamed of doing it.
''If silver turns to gold this way, I don't know how to feel. My dream was to win gold on the mat.''
Another American, Tara Nott, received a gold medal in weight lifting after Izabela Dragneva of Bulgaria was disqualified.

C. J. Hunter, the American shot-putter who withdrew from the Olympics because of arthroscopic knee surgery, tested positive in July for nandrolone, but blamed the elevated level of the drug in his system on a mislabeled nutritional supplement.
After leaving the I.O.C. hearing in Lausanne, Switzerland, Leipold said that nandrolone is ''not the kind of drug you take for wrestling.''
''You wrestle for 26 years and you make medals step by step,'' he said. ''In Germany, I'm always tested out of competition. Every time, I'm clean.''
But Prince Alexander de Merode, chairman of the medical commission, said Leipold's drug sample showed 20 nanograms of nandrolone per milliliter of urine, or 10 times the established limit.
''When you find 10 times more than the fixed limit, we believe the case is clear,'' de Merode said.

After Slay lost to Leipold, 4-0, he protested that the referee had unfairly penalized him for 3 points. The initial 2-point penalty was assessed because Slay allegedly did not follow the referee's instructions to get into a clinch.
''I gave him plenty of opportunity to get into his lock,'' Slay said of Leipold shortly after the match. ''But he started whining and crying like a baby.''
In anger, Slay refused to let his hand be held up by the referee as Leipold was pronounced the winner. Now, Slay is likely to be named the winner.

''Obviously, we're excited about the prospect of having a champion and we're proud of Brandon,'' said Gary Abbott, a spokesman for USA Wrestling. ''But it's not a final decision yet. We'll have a statement when the I.O.C. makes a decision.''
